revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/120.29.113.43|120.29.113.43]] ([[User talk:120.29.113.43|talk]]) to last revision by Ebyabe. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Korean name|Cho}} {{Infobox person | name = John Cho | image = File:John Cho, 2008.jpg | caption = Cho in 2008 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1972|6|16}} | birth_place = [[Seoul]], [[South Korea]] | birth_name = Cho Yo Han | occupation = Actor | years_active = 1997–present | spouse = {{marriage|Kerri Higuchi|2006}} | children = 2 | religion = | alma_mater = [[University of California, Berkeley|UC Berkeley]] | module = {{Infobox Korean name|child=yes|color=transparent | hangul = 조요한 | hanja = {{lang|ko|{{linktext|趙|約|翰|}}}} | rr = Jo Yo(-)han | mr = Cho Yohan }} }} '''John Cho''' (born '''Cho Yo Han'''; June 16, 1972){{cite web| url= http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/john-cho/bio/157818/ | title= John Cho Biography| publisher=[[TV Guide|TVGuide.com]] | accessdate= July 7, 2016|archivedate=September 20, 2015|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150920130151/http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/john-cho/bio/157818/|deadurl=yes}} is a Korean-American actor. He is best known as Harold Lee in the ''[[Harold & Kumar]]'' films; John (MILF Guy No. 2), who popularized the term "[[MILF (slang)|MILF]]" in the ''[[American Pie (film)|American Pie]]'' films; and [[Hikaru Sulu]] in the ''[[Star Trek (film)|Star Trek]]'' [[Star Trek (film series)#Rebootfilms|reboot film series]]. Early in his career, Cho also starred in the [[Asian American]] centered films ''[[Better Luck Tomorrow]]'' (2002), ''[[Shopping for Fangs]]'' (1997), and ''[[Yellow (1998 film)|Yellow]]'' (1998). He starred in the 2018 psychological thriller film ''[[Searching (film)|Searching]]'', making him the first Asian-American actor in history to headline a mainstream thriller film in Hollywood. On television, Cho played [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] agent [[Characters in FlashForward (television show)#Main characters|Demetri Noh]] in the [[science fiction]] television drama ''[[FlashForward]]''; Chau Presley on the [[sitcom]] ''[[Off Centre]]''; Andy Brooks in the horror drama ''[[Sleepy Hollow (TV series)|Sleepy Hollow]]'', Henry Higgs in the 2014 sitcom ''[[Selfie (TV series)|Selfie]]'', and Andrew Kim in ''[[The Exorcist (TV series)|The Exorcist]]''. == Early life == Cho was born in [[Seoul]], South Korea, and moved to the United States in 1978 as a young boy. He was raised in [[Los Angeles]], where his family settled after living in [[Houston]], [[Seattle]], [[Daly City, California]], and [[Monterey Park, California]].{{cite web| url = http://www.asiaarts.ucla.edu/090703/article.asp?parentID=110087 | publisher=Asia Pacific Arts ([[UCLA Asia Institute]])| title= The Game-Changer: An Interview with John Cho | date= July 3, 2009| first= Oliver| last= Wang| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140121080301/http://www.asiaarts.ucla.edu/090703/article.asp?parentID=110087 | archivedate=January 21, 2014}} His father was a minister in the [[Churches of Christ|Church of Christ]], and was originally from North Korea.''Kevin Pollak's Chat Show,'' Hulu.com and Ustream, episode 96{{cite web|title = What to watch|url = http://www.aoltv.com/2011/10/27/john-cho-kal-penn-different-white-house-experiences-video/|website = AOL.com|accessdate = 2015-12-02}} Cho graduated from [[Herbert Hoover High School (Glendale)|Herbert Hoover High School]], in [[Glendale, California]], in 1990. He then attended the [[University of California, Berkeley]], graduating in 1996 with a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] degree in English,{{cite web|url=http://www.answers.com/topic/john-cho|title=John Cho}} and taught English at [[Pacific Hills School]] in [[West Hollywood, California]] while working at [[East West Players]]'s theater in downtown [[Los Angeles]]. == Career == Cho began his career after graduating from Berkeley, when he moved to Los Angeles and worked with the [[Asian American theatre]] company [[East West Players]]. There, he appeared in Edward Sakamoto's ''The Taste of Kona Coffee'' in 1996, and in Euijoon Kim's movie ''My Tired Broke Ass Pontificating Slapstick Funk'' in 2000.[http://eastwestplayers.org/about_us/production_history/mybrokeass.htm EWP 34th Season] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110406114333/http://www.eastwestplayers.org/about_us/production_history/mybrokeass.htm |date=2011-04-06 }} on [[East West Players]] site He gained attention with a small role as "MILF Guy #2" in the 1999 comedy ''[[American Pie (film)|American Pie]]'', in which he popularized the slang term "[[MILF (slang)|MILF]]". Cho reprised the role in three sequels: ''[[American Pie 2]]'', ''[[American Wedding]]'', and in the latest installment ''[[American Reunion]]'' in which he has a much larger role. The character initially had no name but he was given the name "John" in the third film, named after Cho himself. Cho guest-starred on ''[[Dead Man Dating|Charmed]]'' as a [[ghost]] in 1998 and was one of the stars of the short-lived situation comedy ''[[Off Centre]]'' in 2001–2002. He was a costar of the now-defunct [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] sitcom ''[[Kitchen Confidential (TV series)|Kitchen Confidential]]'' based on [[Anthony Bourdain]]'s [[Kitchen Confidential: Adventures in the Culinary Underbelly|best-selling book]]. He had supporting roles in ''[[Evolution (2001 film)|Evolution]]'', a [[science fiction|sci-fi]] comedy directed by [[Ivan Reitman]], ''[[Down to Earth (2001 film)|Down to Earth]]'', starring [[Chris Rock]], and ''[[Bowfinger]]'', with [[Steve Martin]]. In 2002, he had a starring role in the ensemble cast of [[Justin Lin]]'s ''[[Better Luck Tomorrow]]'', a drama focusing on the travails of a group of [[Asian American]]s living in Southern California who are academically successful but socially discontented, and as a result engage in wantonly violent, criminal behavior. It was well received by critics, with the ''New York Times's'' Elvis Mitchell describing Cho's character's "lazy magnetism of which he is charmingly aware."{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/11/movies/film-review-teenagers-determined-to-damage-their-resumes.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|title=Film Review; Teenages Determined to Damage Their Resumes|first=Elvis|last=Mitchell|accessdate=26 August 2012|work=The New York Times|date=2003-04-11}} Later that year, the movie Big Fat Liar was released, in which Cho played a Hong Kong-based movie director. He refused to do the accent scripted for his character. The director worked with him to re-develop the role.Sullivan, Gail (October 9, 2014), [https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2014/10/09/john-cho-of-selfie-wants-roles-outside-any-asian-stereotype-2/ "John Cho of ‘Selfie': ‘I experienced racism’"]. The Washington Post. Retrieved June 16, 2015. He had a successful starring role as Harold Lee in 2004's [[Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle]] and reprised the role in 2008's ''[[Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay]],'' which raked in $38 million at the theaters,{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=haroldandkumar2.htm|title=Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay|publisher=boxofficemojo.com}} and again in 2011's ''[[A Very Harold & Kumar 3D Christmas]]'' which made $35 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=haroldandkumar3.htm|title=A Very Harold & Kumar 3D Christmas|publisher=boxofficemojo.com}} Cho's role in the popular franchise was written specifically for him by [[Hayden Schlossberg]], and Cho has recounted that when Schlossberg first approached him with the role, he was initially suspicious. Cho appeared on July 2004 issue of ''[[KoreAm Journal]]'' and in September 2006 was cast in NBC's new comedy ''[[The Singles Table]]'', but the series never aired due to changes in scheduling and production. In 2006 and again in 2009,[http://www.people.com/people/package/gallery/0,,20315920_20320457,00.html#20705500 People Magazine Sexiest Men Alive 2009] Cho was selected as one of the sexiest men alive in ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine. [[File:10.8.17TheExorcistByLuigiNovi043.jpg|thumb|Cho, right, promoting ''[[The Exorcist (TV series)|The Exorcist]]'' at the 2017 [[New York Comic Con]]. Beside him are his co-stars (left to right) [[Ben Daniels]], [[Zuleikha Robinson]], and [[Kurt Egyiawan]].]] In 2007, Cho was added to the cast of ''[[Ugly Betty]]'' as a recurring character. Cho plays Kenny, a best friend of accountant [[Henry Grubstick]] (played by [[Christopher Gorham]]). Cho played helmsman [[Hikaru Sulu]] in [[J. J. Abrams]]'s feature film ''[[Star Trek (film)|Star Trek]]''.{{cite news |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/news/e3if4ef26bbb490c2c53a944c8e92a50006 |date=2007-10-12|title=Final frontier for Cho, Pegg|author=Borys Kit}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/SHOWBIZ/Movies/03/12/john.cho.ap/index.html|title=John Cho: 'Trek' role is 'daunting'|agency=Associated Press|publisher=CNN|date=2008-03-12}} Manohla Dargis of ''The New York Times'' praised him, along with [[Anton Yelchin]], [[Chris Pine]], and [[Zachary Quinto]], for making their roles "ultimately and rather wonderfully their own".{{cite news |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/2009/05/08/movies/08trek.html |title=Movie Review: 'Star Trek' |author=[[Manohla Dargis]] |date=7 May 2009|accessdate=27 Aug 2012}} Cho appeared in [[Nas]]' "[[Be a Nigger Too]]" music video along with various celebrities, and had a guest appearance on the sitcom ''[[How I Met Your Mother]]'', in the episode "[[I'm Not That Guy]]" where he played a partner in an evil law firm. Of the latter, Staci Krause of [[IGN]], wrote that Cho was "the scene stealer in this episode" and that she would "definitely like to see more of him" in the series.{{cite web |publisher=IGN |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2007/10/30/how-i-met-your-mother-im-not-that-guy-review |title= How I Met Your Mother: 'I'm Not That Guy' Review |date=2007-10-30}} From 2009 to 2010, Cho starred in the television series ''[[FlashForward]]'' as FBI Special Agent [[Demetri Noh]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Fall-TV-ABC-1006175.aspx|title=Fall TV: ABC's Official Schedule Revisits V, Moves Betty and Says Adieu to Who?|author=[[Joyce Eng]]|work=[[TV Guide]]|date=2009-05-19}} His character was originally slated to be killed off during what turned out to be the show's only season, but after his turn as Sulu in ''Star Trek'' boosted his popularity, the producers revised the show's storyline so that he survived, in an attempt to boost declining ratings.{{cite web|last=Keck|first=William|authorlink=William Keck|title=Keck's Exclusives: Gabrielle Union FlashForwards to New Series|url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Kecks-Exclusives-Gabrielle-1019728.aspx|work=TV Guide|date=June 18, 2010|accessdate=July 9, 2010}} He starred as Henry Higgs in the short-lived sitcom ''[[Selfie (TV series)|Selfie]]'', a retooling of the play ''[[Pygmalion (play)|Pygmalion]]'' by [[George Bernard Shaw]],Doll, Jen (October 20, 2014), [https://www.bloomberg.com/bw/articles/2014-10-16/review-abcs-selfie-fails-to-get-the-internet-right "YOU CAN’T DO THAT ON TELEVISION]." ''Business Week''. (4399):70{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/2014-year-in-review/was-2014-banner-year-asian-americans-television-n271176|title=Was 2014 A Banner Year for Asian Americans on Television?| publisher=[[NBC News]] | date=December 27, 2014| accessdate= August 20, 2017| archivedate= August 20, 2017| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170820131023/http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/2014-year-in-review/was-2014-banner-year-asian-americans-television-n271176 |deadurl=no}} becoming the first Asian to play a romantic lead on a U.S. television series. In 2018 he starred in the film ''[[Searching (film)|Searching]]'', which was the first mainstream thriller headlined by an Asian-American actor in Hollywood.{{cite web|last=General |first=Ryan |url=https://nextshark.com/john-cho-searching-thriller-asian-actor/ |title=John Cho Makes History as the First Asian Actor Leading a Hollywood Thriller in 'Searching' |publisher=Nextshark.com |date=2018-07-25 |accessdate=2018-07-29}} ==Musical career== Cho is the lead singer for Viva La Union (formerly known as Left of Zed),{{cite news|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/person/224268/John-Cho/biography|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2005-03-12|title=John Cho|author=Jason Buchanan}} a Los Angeles [[garage rock]] band composed of former [[University of California at Berkeley|Berkeley]] and [[University of Southern California|USC]] students. They have one album, self-titled, while their song "Chinese Baby" is featured on the [[Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay#Soundtrack|''Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay'' soundtrack]]. == Being an Asian American in Hollywood == Cho has indicated he has found freedom in being Harold in the ''Harold and Kumar'' films because the stoner character goes against the grain of Asian Americans onscreen.{{cite web|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=94HUM3S_Gzg|title = John Cho On Playing The Asian-American Stoner Stereotype |work= Larry King Now|date = |accessdate = |last = |first = }} He has said he has experienced racism throughout his career in Hollywood and that he tries to take roles that do not perpetuate Asian stereotypes.{{cite web|title = In 'Selfie', John Cho Gets An Unlikely Shot As A Romantic Lead|url = https://www.npr.org/blogs/codeswitch/2014/09/28/352046466/selfie-s-choice-john-cho-gets-an-unlikely-shot-as-a-romantic-lead|publisher = [[National Public Radio]] |accessdate = 2015-12-02}} When asked to do an Asian accent for ''Big Fat Liar'', Cho refused. "I don't want to do this role in a kid's comedy, with an accent, because I don't want young people laughing at an accent inadvertently", he wrote.{{Cite news|title = John Cho of 'Selfie': 'I experienced racism'|url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2014/10/09/john-cho-of-selfie-wants-roles-outside-any-asian-stereotype-2/|newspaper = The Washington Post|date = 2014-10-09|access-date = 2015-11-30|issn = 0190-8286|language = en-US|first = Gail|last = Sullivan}} In a 2015 tweet he said, "[[Whitewashing in film|Stop turning Asian roles white]]. It's bullshit and we all know it."{{Cite tweet|first=John (verified account)|last=Cho|title=Stop turning Asian roles white.| date=March 24, 2015|user=JohnTheCho|number=580552681711923200|accessdate = November 30, 2015| archivedate=May 11, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160511023752/https://twitter.com/johnthecho/status/580552681711923200| deadurl=no}} On being the first Asian to play a romantic lead on a U.S. television series, he described it as being "revolutionary" and a "personal revolution" for him because of its uniqueness in Hollywood. "Asians narratively in shows are insignificant. They're the cop, or waitress, or whatever it is. You see them in the background. So to be in this position ... is bit of a landmark," he has said on the inability of Asians getting offered such roles.{{cite web|title = Will John Cho Be Television's First Asian Romantic Lead?|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/victoria-namkung/tvs-first-asian-romantic-lead_b_5878380.html|website = The Huffington Post|accessdate = 2015-12-02}}{{Cite news|title = "Asians narratively in shows are insignificant," says John Cho, the romantic lead in the fall series Selfie. "So to be in this position ... is a bit of a landmark."|url = https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/television/2014/07/16/star_treks_john_cho_breaks_barriers_as_romantic_lead_i_would_call_this_revolutionary.html|newspaper = The Toronto Star|date = 2014-07-16|access-date = 2015-11-30|issn = 0319-0781|first = Tony|last = Wong}} ==Personal life== Cho married actress Kerri Higuchi in 2006 and has a son, born in 2008,{{cite web|title=John Cho and wife Kerri expecting first child|url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2008/04/13/john-cho-and-wi/|publisher=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=April 13, 2008|accessdate=December 9, 2012}} and a daughter, born in 2013.{{cite web|title=John Cho and wife Kerri have second child|url= http://celebritybabies.people.com/2013/02/11/go-on-identity-thief-john-cho-welcomes-a-daughter/?xid=rss-topheadlines|publisher=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=February 11, 2013|accessdate=February 11, 2013}} As of 2015, he and his family reside in Los Angeles, California.{{cite web|title = John Cho|url = http://www.tv.com/people/john-cho/biography/|website = TV.com|accessdate = 2015-12-01}} He supported the 2012 re-election campaign of Democratic U.S. President [[Barack Obama]].(2011-07-16) {{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0711/59184.html |title=Hollywood stars open wallets for Obama |date= |accessdate=2011-07-16}} He is close to his father, a former preacher, and would like to play a role in the story of his father's generation in North Korea when growing up through the [[Korean War]] in times of hardships. == Filmography == === Film === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! Notes |- | rowspan=2|1997 | ''[[Wag the Dog]]'' | Aide #3 | |- | ''[[Shopping for Fangs]]'' | Clarence | |- | 1998 | ''[[Yellow (1998 film)|Yellow]]'' | Joey | |- | rowspan=3|1999 | ''[[American Beauty (1999 film)|American Beauty]]'' | Sale House Man #1 | |- | ''[[Bowfinger]]'' | Nightclub Cleaner | |- | ''[[American Pie (film)|American Pie]]'' | MILF Guy #2 | |- | 2000 | ''[[The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas]]'' | Parking Valet | |- | rowspan=5|2001 | ''[[Delivering Milo]]'' | Mr. Hugo | |- | ''[[American Pie 2]]'' | John (MILF Guy #2) | |- | ''[[Evolution (2001 film)|Evolution]]'' | Student | |- | ''[[Down to Earth (2001 film)|Down to Earth]]'' | Phil Quon | |- | ''[[Pavilion of Women]]'' | Fengmo Wu | |- | rowspan=3|2002 | ''[[Better Luck Tomorrow]]'' | Steve Choe | |- | ''[[Solaris (2002 film)|Solaris]]'' | DBA Emissary #1 | |- | ''[[Big Fat Liar]]'' | Dustin Wong | |- | 2003 | ''[[American Wedding]]'' | John | |- | rowspan=3|2004 | ''[[In Good Company (2004 film)|In Good Company]]'' | Petey | |- | ''[[Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle]]'' | Harold Lee | |- | ''[[See This Movie]]'' | Larry Finkelstein | |- | rowspan=2|2006 | ''[[American Dreamz]]'' | Frank Ittles | |- | ''[[Bickford Shmeckler's Cool Ideas]]'' | Tom | |- | rowspan=2|2007 | ''[[West 32nd]]'' | John Kim | |- | ''[[Smiley Face (film)|Smiley Face]]'' | Mike | |- | rowspan=3|2008 | ''[[Nick and Norah's Infinite Playlist]]'' | Hype Man | |- | ''[[Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay]]'' | rowspan="2"| Harold Lee | |- | ''Harold & Kumar Go to Amsterdam'' | Short film |- | rowspan=2|2009 | ''[[Star Trek (film)|Star Trek]]'' | [[Hikaru Sulu]] | [[Boston Society of Film Critics Award for Best Cast]]
Nominated — [[Broadcast Film Critics Association Award for Best Cast]] |- | ''[[Saint John of Las Vegas]]'' | Carnival Human Torch | |- | 2011 | ''[[A Very Harold & Kumar 3D Christmas]]'' | Harold Lee | |- | rowspan=2|2012 | ''[[American Reunion]]'' | John | |- | ''[[Total Recall (2012 film)|Total Recall]]'' | Bob McClane | |- | rowspan=3|2013 | ''[[Identity Thief]]'' | Daniel Casey | |- | ''[[Star Trek Into Darkness]]'' | Hikaru Sulu | |- | ''[[The Tale of the Princess Kaguya]]'' | Middle Counselor Isonokami (voice) | English dub |- | rowspan=2|2015 | ''[[Zipper (film)|Zipper]]'' | EJ | |- | ''[[Grandma (film)|Grandma]]'' | Chau | |- | rowspan=2|2016 | ''[[Get a Job (2016 film)|Get a Job]]'' | Brian Bender | |- | ''[[Star Trek Beyond]]'' | Hikaru Sulu | |- | rowspan=4|2017 | ''[[Columbus (2017 film)|Columbus]]'' | Jin | |- | ''[[Gemini (2017 film)|Gemini]]'' | Detective Edward Ahn | |- | ''[[Literally, Right Before Aaron]]'' | Mark | |- | ''[[A Happening of Monumental Proportions]]'' | | |- | rowspan=2|2018 | ''[[Searching (film)|Searching]]'' | David Kim | |- | ''[[The Oath (2018 film)|The Oath]]'' | Peter | ''Post-production'' |- | rowspan=2|2019 |''The Wish Dragon''[https://variety.com/2018/film/asia/china-wish-dragon-sony-jackie-chan-basefx-1202780374/ Jackie Chan, China’s BaseFX Making ‘Wish Dragon’ for Sony Animation] |(voice) |''In production'' |- | ''[[The Grudge (2019 film)|The Grudge]]'' | | ''Filming'' |} === Television === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year !! Title !! Role !! Notes |- | 1997 | ''[[The Jeff Foxworthy Show]]'' | Pizza Delivery Man | Episode: "Twister of Fate" |- | 1998 | ''[[Felicity (TV series)|Felicity]]'' | Larry | Episode: "The Last Stand" |- | 1998 | ''[[Charmed]]'' | Mark Chao | Episode: "Dead Man Dating" |- | 2001 | ''[[Static Shock]]'' | Thomas Kim/Tantrum, Navigator (voices) | 2 episodes |- | 2001–02 | ''[[Off Centre]]'' | Chau Presley | 28 episodes |- | 2002 | ''[[The Jamie Kennedy Experiment]]'' | Himself | 1 episode |- | 2003 | ''[[Kim Possible]]'' | Hirotaka (voice) | Episode: "Exchange" |- | 2005 | ''[[The Men's Room]]'' | Bob | 4 episodes |- | 2005 | ''[[House (TV series)|House M.D.]]'' | Harvey Park | Episode: "[[Love Hurts (House)|Love Hurts]]" |- | 2005–06 | ''[[Kitchen Confidential (TV series)|Kitchen Confidential]]'' | Teddy Wong | 10 episodes |- | 2006 | ''[[Grey's Anatomy]]'' | Marshall Stone | Episode: "Damage Case" |- | 2006–13 | ''[[American Dad!]]'' | Vince Chung (voice) | 4 episodes |- | 2007 | ''[[How I Met Your Mother]]'' | Jefferson Coatsworth | Episode: "[[I'm Not That Guy]]" |- | 2007 | ''[[Ugly Betty]]'' | Kenny | 3 episodes |- | 2007 | ''[['Til Death]]'' | Lucas Bender | Episode: "Come Out and Play" |- | 2008 | ''[[Hollywood Residential]]'' | Himself | Episode: "It Happens" |- | 2009–10 | ''[[FlashForward]]'' | Demetri Noh | 22 episodes |- | 2010 | ''[[Childrens Hospital]]'' | Park | Episode: "Frankfurters. Allman Brothers. Death. Frankfurters" |- | 2011 | ''[[30 Rock]]'' | Lorne | Episode: "Double-Edged Sword" |- | 2011 | ''[[NTSF:SD:SUV::]]'' | Chip | Episode: "The Birthday Part That Was Neither" |- | 2012–13 | ''[[Go On (TV series)|Go On]]'' | Steven | 22 episodes |- | 2013–14 | ''[[Sleepy Hollow (TV series)|Sleepy Hollow]]'' | Andy Brooks | 7 episodes |- | 2014 | ''[[Selfie (TV series)|Selfie]]'' | Henry Higgs | Main cast; 13 episodes |- | 2015 | ''[[BoJack Horseman]]'' | Lead Improv-er (voice) | Episode: "Yes And" |- | 2015 | ''[[The Mindy Project]]'' | Big Murder | Episode: "Lahiri Family Values" |- | 2016 | ''[[New Girl]]'' | Daniel | Episode: "Jury Duty" |- | 2016 | ''[[House of Lies]]'' | Sean Chew | Episode: "Holacracy" |- | 2016 | ''[[Drunk History]]'' | [[William Shakespeare]] | Episode: "Landmarks" |- | 2016 | ''The Hindenburg Explodes!'' | Reggie | Pilot |- | 2017 | ''[[Difficult People]]'' | Todd Ross | 4 episodes |- | 2017 | ''[[The Exorcist (TV series)|The Exorcist]]'' | Andrew Kim | 10 episodes |- | 2017 | ''[[Do You Want To See a Dead Body?]]'' | Himself | Episode: "A Body and Some Quicksand" |} ===Web series=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role |- | 2015 | ''Parallel Man: Infinite Pursuit'' | Agent Nick Morgan (voice) |} ===Video games=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! class="unsortable" | Notes |- | 2013 | ''[[Star Trek (2013 video game)|Star Trek]]'' | Hikaru Sulu | Also likeness |} == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{IMDb name|158626}} * {{Tcmdb name}} * {{Twitter}} * {{amg name|224268}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cho, John}} [[Category:1972 births]] [[Category:American male actors of Korean descent]] [[Category:20th-century American male actors]] [[Category:21st-century American male actors]] [[Category:American male film actors]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:American singers]] [[Category:American male television actors]] [[Category:American schoolteachers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Male actors from Los Angeles]] [[Category:Male actors from Seoul]] [[Category:South Korean emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:University of California, Berkeley alumni]]
